Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Hybrid Solar Panel for Radiative Thermal Exchange
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to catalyze the domestic market for renewable solar heating and cooling. Over 50% of the world's energy provides heating and cooling for residential, commercial and industrial applications, most of which is generated from the combustion of fossil fuels. The basis for this work is a low-cost panelized solution for renewable solar heat collection incorporating a cooling component at night. For multi-family homes, this singular approach will make it possible to satisfy more than 60% of the hot water, space heating, and space cooling demands. This solution could address up to 4,400 TBtu of this demand, a $34 B opportunity, while reducing electricity consumption and demand for refrigerants.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will build on the proven solar heat architecture. The current solar heat only solution will be modified to enhance its inherent radiative cooling capability. The effort will focus on identifying and specifying novel polymer and fluoropolymer films whose emittance and transmission properties can be enhanced. After optical characterization, sample films of interest will be fabricated at scale for inclusion into a full-sized test panel to be evaluated using an in-house solar simulator and ultimately via field testing. The work will also require modifications to the panel architecture to decrease the heat absorbed from the environment. The result will be an extension of the solar heat product family. Cooling rates as high as 100 W/m2 are theoretically possible.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MMCISolar’s Phase I SBIR project achieved multiple outcomes related to improving the performance of the radiative cooling capabilities of the AirPane Thermal Pane. The work began by identifying optimal engineered and off the shelf material candidates to increase the mid-IR emissivity of the Thermal Pane. This outcome was achieved by utilizing optical techniques to measure the absorptivity of a comprehensive set of material samples in the 8 micron to 13 micron range. Focusing on this range is important because it aligns very well with the Earth’s atmospheric window and thus enables radiative heat rejection to the upper atmosphere. The resulting pool of candidates was down selected by a combination of passive low fidelity and active high fidelity experimental platforms. These platforms were designed and constructed for the project to measure radiative cooling rates in an outdoor environment. The active platform comprised several radiative panels with programmable tracking temperature modes that enabled multiple real world cooling scenarios to be emulated during nighttime testing. In particular scenarios related to the direct cooling of a building interior and the indirect cooling, via an intervening vapor compression system, were emulated. The combination of low and high fidelity measurements led to the discovery of several commercially available low-cost silicone based polymer coatings with good emissive characteristics. Two fluoropolymer infrared window materials were also identified and tested in combination with the silicone coating. Multiple active tests of these material combinations revealed that radiative cooling rates could be improved by up to 14X, much higher than the 5X that was originally projected. The choice of materials has also contributed to a design revision of the Pane architecture enabling it to passively avoid overheating events.

 

Overall the work confirms that the original AirPane architecture, optimized for solar heating only, can now incorporate radiative cooling at a rate that makes it economically attractive. The revised architecture known as AirPaneX, will serve as the basis for a new platform for providing space and water heating as well as space cooling energy resources for building applications. This overarching outcome could provide the basis for a new and powerful tool to be utilized in reducing greenhouse gas emissions from both commercial and residential buildings. The ability to provide heating and cooling will lower the overall capital cost of such platform making it competitive with dominant sources of heating and cooling in the form of natural gas and vapor compression air conditioning. Economic competitiveness will enable deployment to a much larger range of applications across the U.S. and the world, providing thousands of new job opportunities in the renewable energy industry.
